metadata.title: Carbon nano-dots as a fluorescent and colorimetric dual-readout probe for the detection of arginine and Cu and its logic gate operation†

sections.heading: Nanoscale
sections.text:

Received 2nd April 2017, Accepted 13th July 2017

rsc.li/nanoscale
Carbon nano-dots as a fluorescent and colorimetric dual-readout probe for the detection of arginine and Cu2+ and its logic gate operation†
Wenjing Lu,a Yifang Gao,a Yuan Jiao,a Shaomin Shuang,a Chenzhong Lib and Chuan Dong *a
A new visual fluorescent probe based on carbon nano-dots (CNDs) has been facilely synthesized via one step microwave-assisted pyrolysis and utilized for sequential detection of arginine (Arg) and Cu2+ by fluo-
rescent and colorimetric dual-readout assay. The fluorescence of CNDs can be effectively quenched by Arg, and recovered upon addition of Cu2+ due to the competitive binding of Arg and Cu2+ that leads Arg
to escape from the surface of CNDs. The probe displayed high sensitivity and selectivity toward Arg and Cu2+ over other analytes with a low detection limit of 0.26 μM and 0.17 μM, respectively. Meanwhile, the CNDs can also give dual responsive signals of a visible color change (yellow–pink–light yellow).
According to this phenomenon, an “AND” logic gate based on the novel CNDs has been constructed.
More importantly, the probe was also extended to cellular imaging. The proposed method was simple
with ease of operation, which demonstrated great potential in bio-sensing, disease diagnosis or environ-
mental monitoring.

sections.heading: Introduction
sections.text:
Amino acids as the basic units of biological macromolecular proteins and the essential components of life processes have been intensively investigated.1–3 Selective recognition and analysis of amino acids at the molecular level are highly demanded especially in medical diagnosis of diseases.4–6 Among all the amino acids, arginine (Arg) plays a key role in many biological functions, including cell division, wound healing, immune function, blood vessel dilation and the release of hormones.7–9 Moreover, it is also vital as it is the immediate physiological precursor of nitric oxide, urea, ornithine and agmatine.9–11 If the levels of Arg-derived species are abnormal, this can cause some diseases and even be life threatening.2,12 For instance, excessive L-arginine can increase the level of stomach acid, and particularly some people experience anaphylaxis. But if there is a lack of arginine, it can also lead to blood ammonia imbalance and even coma. Thus, argi-
nine can be used as a possible diagnostic indicator for some diseases.13,14 These important facts show the necessity to develop feasible methods for arginine detection in clinical disease diagnosis.
Currently major methods for the detection of the Arg are high-performance liquid chromatography (HPLC)10 and gas chromatography (GC).15 However, these methods usually involve specialized and expensive equipment, complex sample pretreatment and long determination time.9,16 Therefore, many researchers try to design chemical sensors to analyze Arg. Moreover, due to the highly hydrophilic properties and the weak interactions between the receptors and Arg in aqueous media, the sensors for Arg are still very scarce compared to numerous receptors for amino acids with the aromatic or thiol group such as cysteine (Cys) and tyrosine (Tyr).3,17–19 Only a few sensors20–23 are available for the detection of Arg: Cao et al.5 designed a ternary system of fluorophore-surfactant assembly-Cu2+ for selective responses to Arg by electrostatic interactions. Parveen et al.4 used a naturally occurring molecule plumbagin as a sensing probe for the detection of Arg based on intermolecular proton transfer. However, the majority of probes are subjected to complex preparation procedures or are toxic, which may be problematic for practical application under biological conditions.3,22,24,25 In addition, if the probe possesses both colorimetric and fluorescent dual response behaviors, it will make visual detection †Electronic supplementary information (ESI) available. possible. Therefore, to develop a simple, inexpensive, effective and selective method for the recognition of Arg in total aqueous solution is highly desirable.9
Copper, as an essential trace and vital transition metal element which is the third abundant in the human body, plays a pivotal role in a wide number of physiological and pathological processes such as enzyme activity and inhibition of cell metabolism. Abnormal content of copper may cause various diseases, such as Wilson’s disease, Parkinson’s disease, and Alzheimer’s disease.26–29 Besides, as a heavy metal, an excess of copper in water or soil can also lead to serious environmental problems. Thus, it is rewarding to develop accurate, high-performance, low-cost and eco-friendly strategies for copper ion (Cu2+) detection in biomedicine and environmental sciences.30–32
Carbon dots (CDs) have gained considerable attention from the scientific community in recent years due to numerous superior features such as easy preparation and functionalization, good biocompatibility and low toxicity.33–36 They have become excellent candidates for alternative semiconductor quantum dots that usually comprise toxic heavy metals.9,37 Thus, all of the outstanding properties demonstrate that CDs as novel nanoparticles can be used in sensing, medical diagnosis, drug delivery, catalysis and so on.33,36–42 Among these applications, it is fascinating to use CDs as effective optical sensors to monitor metal ions,43–45 small biomolecules,46,47 and proteins48,49 in biosensing and imaging. For example, Zhu et al.34 synthesized nitrogen-doped carbon dots as a turnon fluorescent probe for rapid analysis of His. Jiang et al.33 found that CDs as a bifunctional sensing platform show “ON– OFF–ON” three-state emission with the stepwise addition of Ag+ and Cys. Inspired by the above results, it is still very meaningful to develop a fluorescent sensing platform via the excellent optical properties of CDs for selective recognition of Arg.
So our strategy herein was to construct a dual-mode carbon nano-dot (CND) probe with both colorimetric and fluorometric readouts for the stepwise detection of Arg and Cu2+. The CNDs were synthesized by using chitosan, ethanolamine and acetic acid as precursors through a facile and eco-friendly process. The obtained CNDs exhibited excellent photostability, biocompatibility, low toxicity and multicolor cellular labeling capability. The fluorescence of CNDs is significantly decreased in the presence of Arg by static quenching owing to the formation of a CNDs–Arg complex. Accordingly, the color of the solution turns from yellow to pink. Interestingly, on adding Cu2+ to the CNDs–Arg system subsequently, the interaction between Cu2+ and Arg becomes stronger, which leads to removal of Arg from the CNDs. The fluorescence of the CNDs– Arg ensemble is restored and the color of the solution recovers to light yellow. Therefore, the system can be turned on. Compared with one kind of output signal, fluorometric and colorimetric dual-mode sensing assays spark significant excitement due to the fact that they present a response more conveniently and rapidly, and thus enable more convincing analytical results.47,50,51 Furthermore, the analytical method was also successfully employed in intracellular imaging. And
an “AND” logic gate using CNDs as a new material was also established. It may open up a new route for constructing chemical logic gates via fluorescent sensors. All the above mentioned results prove that our as-synthesized CNDs present great prospect in biosensing, disease diagnosis and environmental monitoring (Scheme 1).

sections.heading: Materials
sections.text: Chitosan, ethanediamine (EDA) and glacial acetic acid were obtained from Aladdin (USA). Amino acids including arginine (Arg), methionine (Met), cysteine (Cys), histidine (His), leucine (Leu), lysine (Lys), proline (Pro), tryptophan (Trp), glycine (Gly), alanine (Ala), valine (Val), threonine (Thr), phenylalanine (Phe), tyrosine (Tyr), aspartic acid (Asp), serine (Ser), isoleucine (Ile) and glutamic acid (Glu) were purchased from SigmaAldrich Chemical Co. (USA). Other reagents were acquired from Aladdin Ltd (Shanghai, China). All chemicals were of analytical reagent grade and used as received without any further purification. Ultrapure water (≥18.25 MΩ cm) from a molecular purification system (Shanghai, China) was used in all experiments.

sections.heading: Synthesis of CNDs
sections.text: The water-soluble CNDs were synthesized by a fast one-pot microwave assisted pyrolysis method and according to our previous work.52 0.5 g chitosan was sufficiently mixed with 5.0 mL 8.0% glacial acetic acid, and 3.0 mL EDA were loaded into a 10 mL beaker to form a paste under constant stirring. Subsequently, the mixture was transferred into a domestic microwave oven and heated for 15 min under high-power mode. After carbonization, the product was dispersed in 30 mL of ultrapure water and cooled down to ambient temperature naturally. Then the brown dispersion was dialyzed against ultrapure water using a dialysis membrane (MWCO = 500–1000) for 72 h after filtering. Finally, the obtained clear yellow aqueous solution was lyophilized in a vacuum freeze dryer to collect dry CNDs.

For the detection of Cu2+, the CNDs solution (0.5 mg mL−1) was first mixed with Arg (120 μM), and then various concentrations of Cu2+ were added. After that the fluorescence spectra of the mixture were recorded (λex at 365 nm). sections.heading: Cellular imaging
sections.text:
Human liver cancer HepG 2 cells were maintained in DMEM supplemented with 10% FBS (v/v) at 37 °C under a 5% CO2 humidified atmosphere. The cells were seeded in a culture dish and incubated for 24 h. Then, the original culture medium was replaced with fresh 0.5 mg mL−1 CNDs. The HepG 2 cells were incubated for another 6 h. Further, followed by removal of the excess medium, each dish was washed three times (1.0 mL each) with phosphate buffered saline (PBS, pH = 7.4). Imaging of cells was performed using an Olympus FV1000 confocal microscope (Tokyo, Japan). Subsequently, for verifying the detection of the probe for Arg and Cu2+, 15 μL of Arg with a concentration of 10.0 mM was added into the system. Then, 10 μL Cu2+ solution with a concentration of 10.0 mM was introduced into the sample slowly. Finally, the
samples were observed using a laser scanning confocal microscope.

sections.heading: Characterization of the CNDs
sections.text:
The carbon nano-dots (CNDs) were prepared by using a fast, simple and green method reported in our previous work.52 First, a typical transmission electron microscopy (TEM) image, as presented in Fig. 1(A), was obtained to show our as-prepared CNDs. The CNDs were uniformly spherical and well dispersed. The size distribution falls in the range of 2.0–6.0 nm and the average diameter is 3.70 nm (Fig. 1B). In more detail, the graphite-like crystalline structure of CNDs with an interlayer lattice spacing of 0.18 nm can be observed in the high-resolution TEM, which is similar to the (100) diffraction planes of graphite.53,54
Then, the surface composition and elemental analysis of the CNDs were presented by using Fourier transform infrared spectra (FTIR) and X-ray photoelectron spectra (XPS). As shown in the FT-IR spectra in Fig. 1C, a broad absorption peak at 3404 cm−1 is attributed to the O–H stretching vibration. The sharp absorption peaks at 2949 cm−1 and 1699 cm−1 correspond to C–H and CvO, respectively. Moreover, CNDs with distinctive absorption peaks at 1643 cm−1 are ascribed to the N–H vibrations, which identifies the presence of amide groups on CNDs.52 And the typical stretching mode of C–N bands in heterocycles at 1400 cm−1 is observed. In addition, the peaks

at 1000–1200 cm−1 are attributed to C–O, C–N and C–O–C bonds. Meanwhile, in the XPS spectra, Fig. 1D indicates that the CNDs mainly included C, N, and O elements. The C 1s was observed at 285.0 eV. The rest of the peaks at 400.0 and 532.0 eV matched with N 1s and O 1s, respectively. The highresolution C 1s XPS spectrum exhibited the distinctive peaks of C–C/CvC, C–N, C–O and CvO at 284.8, 285.3, 286.7 and 287.9 eV, respectively (Fig. 1E).55 The high-resolution O 1s XPS spectrum showed the peaks of C–OH and CvO at 531.8 and 532.9 eV, respectively (Fig. S1A, ESI†).33 In the N 1s spectrum, additional peaks at 399.6, 400.4, and 401.3 eV, related to pyridine-like N, graphitic N–C3 and amino N were observed (Fig. S1B, ESI†). The results of the XPS spectra were in good agreement with those of FTIR.
Subsequently, the luminescence properties of CNDs such as UV-Vis absorption, fluorescence spectra, quantum yield (QY), lifetime and stability were examined intensively. As depicted in the UV-Vis absorption spectra in Fig. 1F, CNDs exhibited a prominent broad peak at 355–370 nm probably due to the n–π* transition of CvO and the appearance of excited defect surface states induced by the N heteroatoms,52,56,57 which could result in CNDs’ bright fluorescence. In the fluorescence spectra, the CNDs manifested an optimal emission band centered at 454 nm when excited at 365 nm. By choosing quinine sulfate in sulfuric acid as the reference, the QY of the CNDs was calculated to be 23.4% at λex/λem of 365/ 380–680 nm. Furthermore, the fluorescence decay curve of CNDs is well fitted to a double-exponential formula and the calculated average lifetime is about 10.57 ns. In addition, Fig. S2, ESI† depicts the high resistance to photo-bleaching of the CNDs. The fluorescence intensity showed almost no obvious change even after 150 min exposure to xenon arc light, suggesting that CNDs possess good luminescence stability. Simultaneously, the CNDs demonstrated outstanding endurance even under the high ionic-strength conditions (up to 2.0 M NaCl aqueous solution) and independently in broad pH ranges (2–12). They exhibit potential for practical applications.

sections.heading: Fluorescence quenching of CNDs by Arg
sections.text:
Due to the unique nature of abundant functional groups on the surface, we were prompted to further investigate the potential sensing applications of CNDs. Through broad exploration, the fluorescent probe CNDs were found to display excellent properties for the detection of arginine (Arg). When Arg was added into the CNDs solution, the fluorescence of CNDs was quenched quickly. Meanwhile, an apparent change in the color of the solution from yellow to pink was observed. For further exploration of the nature of the quenching process, zeta-potential, UV-Vis absorption spectra and fluorescence lifetime measurements were employed to provide more evidence for the real mechanism. It is known that Arg is an alkaline amino acid and has the highest isoelectric point (pI) at 10.76 compared to other amino acids. It carries positive charge at pH 7.4.2,9,58 Thus, we speculate whether Arg can be attracted by the negative charge on the surfaces of CNDs based on the electrostatic interaction result to change the electron or energy
transfer process and fluorescence quenching of CNDs. To validate this hypothesis, we observed the changes in the zetapotential of the system. However, the negative zeta-potential of the CNDs solution had a negligible change from −17.5 to −15.9 mV in the presence of Arg. And the relative fluorescence intensity of the solution was still independent of pH (2–12) upon addition of Arg before and after (Fig. S3A, ESI†). Besides this, ionic strength would affect the electrostatic interaction,59 however, in Fig. S3B, ESI,† with concentrations of NaCl increasing in the system (up to 2.0 M), the fluorescence intensity and spectral features still remained constant. All these facts imply that fluorescence quenching of CNDs is not caused by the electrostatic attraction between CNDs and Arg.
Fluorescence lifetime is effective evidence to distinguish the quenching type.60 So we researched the fluorescence emission decay curves of the system before and after adding Arg (Fig. S3C, ESI†). The lifetime data of CNDs and CNDs–Arg are calculated to be 10.57 ns and 10.46 ns respectively (Table S1, ESI†), which reveals that the fluorescence quenching of CNDs in the presence of Arg is a static quenching process on account of the formation of the CNDs–Arg complex.60,61 In addition, the consequences of UV-Vis absorption spectra were in accord with this inference. 365 nm (ascribable to the n–π* transition of CvO) undergoes a significant decrease in intensity, and a new band appears at 523 nm under addition of arginine gradually. A vivid sight to the naked eye is the color change from yellow to pink, which implies the formation of the CNDs–Arg complex on the other hand, Because Arg contains the guanidine group different from other amino acids.9,62 These phenomena possibly are interpreted when Arg approaches CNDs, a strong affinity is generated between the guanidine group and the amino or hydroxyl groups of CNDs by its multiple H-bonds,3,63–65 which leads to the formation of the CNDs–Arg complex and influences the electron configuration of CNDs, thus disrupting the charge transfer process and facilitating the non-radiative transition. Therefore, it causes the fluorescence quenching of CNDs and change in the color.60 For the specific quenching mechanism, we will continue to verify in our future work.
To investigate the selectivity of CNDs as a dual-signal probe for the detection of Arg, we surveyed the spectral responses of the probe toward other amino acids. As shown in Fig. 2B, only Arg was able to quench the fluorescence of the CNDs. Besides, when adding Arg to the system, the color of the solution from yellow turned to pink and could be discriminated distinctly (Fig. 2C). Meanwhile, other amino acids produced negligible influence on the UV-Vis absorption spectra of CNDs (Fig. S4, ESI†). Further, we also investigated the limit of detection (LOD) and range of linear detection under optimal conditions. In Fig. 2D, with the increase in the concentration of Arg, a gradual decline in the fluorescence of the system intensity at 454 nm was found. The fluorescence intensity of the CNDs decreased to about 25% of the primal intensity after the addition of 120 μM Arg. Fig. 2E displays the linear relationship between ΔF and Arg concentration. They have a good linear correlation in the range of 0.8–100 µM with a correlation coefficient R2 of 0.991. The limit of detection (LOD) is estimated to be 0.26 µM for Arg, as calculated according to a signal-to-noise ratio of 3 66 (ΔF = F − F0, where F and F0 are the fluorescence intensities of the CNDs in the presence and absence of Arg, respectively). Apparently, it reveals that our dual-signal readout detection method is more convenient and the sensitivity is comparable or superior to previous studies (Table S2, ESI†).

sections.heading: Fluorescence recovery of CNDs by Cu2+
sections.text:
To our surprise, we found that the quenched fluorescence of the CNDs–Arg (i.e., 0.5 mg mL−1 of CNDs and 120 μM of Arg) can be basically recovered with the addition of Cu2+ and the color of the solution recovered to light yellow, concurrently. The results indicate that the CNDs–Arg complex has the potential to probe Cu2+. According to previous reports, Cu2+ could bind to Arg.5,67,68 This phenomenon probably could be attributed to the fact that Arg preferentially coordinates to Cu2+ via the N atoms from the amino group and guanidine group as well as the O atom from the carboxyl group, when Cu2+ was added to a solution of the CNDs–Arg complex. The competitive coordination of Cu2+ would whittle away the interaction between Arg and CNDs, and Arg could be removed from the surface of CNDs. The CNDs was preferably exchanged with
Cu2+ to form a more stable Arg–Cu complex. As a result, the fluorescence of the system would be dramatically restored.16,28–31,34,55,69,70 The UV-Vis spectra also further support the above explanation. The absorption peak at 523 nm vanishes from sight after the addition of Cu2+ into the CNDs– Arg solution and the absorption peak of CNDs–Arg–Cu2+ is similar to that of pure CNDs (Fig. 3A). In addition, to validate the selectivity of the CNDs–Arg system and the fluorescence enhancement, other numerous metal ions were investigated as control samples. However, none of these control substances had obvious influences on the fluorometric responses; only Cu2+ can make the fluorescence intensity regain (Fig. 3B). As shown in Fig. 3C, introducing Cu2+ slowly could bring a distinct fluorescence restoration of about 80% of the original fluorescence intensity. Fig. 3D indicates a good linear relationship between ΔF and Cu2+ concentration in a linear range from 0.6 μM to 35 μM (ΔF = F − F0, where F and F0 are the fluorescence intensities of the CNDs–Arg in the presence and absence of Cu2+, respectively). The LOD and RSD were estimated to be 0.17 μM and 2.8%, respectively. Based on all the results mentioned above, we can draw a conclusion that the system also has the diagnostic potential for detecting Cu2+.
In vitro cellular imaging examination
These results highlight that CNDs are a good fluorescent probe and as a new fluorescent tag are amenable to cell labeling and imaging applications. The cytotoxicity of CNDs was explored by the standard MTT assay utilizing human hepatoma carcinoma HepG 2 cells as the model. As depicted in Fig. S5, ESI,† the viability of the HepG 2 cells was still higher than 86.75% even upon exposure to a high concentration

Therefore, we utilize CNDs with a concentration of 0.5 mg mL−1 as the experimental condition to incubate with HepG 2 cells for cell imaging experiments, which is lower than that could cause cell damage (Fig. 4a–d). The cells emit multicolors and strong fluorescence under LSCM. Close observations revealed that the CNDs had good cell permeability and were distributed over the cell membrane and cytoplasm area, but not into the cell nucleus. After adding 150 μM Arg, an obvious fluorescence quenching was manifested (Fig. 4e–h). On further treatment of the cells with 100 μM Cu2+, a fluorescence signal could be recovered (Fig. 4i– l). It turns out that the trend of the fluorescence intensity change in vivo coincides with that of in vitro and the entire process only needs several seconds. These results further demonstrate that CNDs are an efficient fluorescent probe for the detection Arg and Cu2+ in live cells.
Logic operation of CNDs towards Arg and Cu2+
On account of the significance of the CNDs–Arg–Cu2+ system exhibiting the ability of “ON–OFF–ON” three-state emission by an external additive stimulus, we designed an “AND” molecular logic gate.50,60,71–74 This logic gate uses Arg and Cu2+ as two inputs and the fluorescence signal recovery as the optical output. The corresponding symbol and truth table of the results of each input mode is given in Fig. 5. For the output, the recovery of fluorescence intensity and no fluorescence recovery were defined as “1” and “0”, respectively. For the input, the presence of inputs (Arg or Cu2+) was defined as 1, and the absence of inputs was defined the 0 state. Therefore, only when the system receives the two inputs together (1, 1), is
the fluorescence signal enhanced visibly, and the gate is activated and exerts an output signal of “1”.51

sections.heading: Conclusions
sections.text: In summary, CNDs were prepared through a rapid, facile and eco-friendly procedure, and they displayed high chemical and optical stabilities with respectable QY and good biocompatibility. From the combination of fluorometric and colorimetric readouts, a dual-mode sensing assay for Arg and Cu2+ screening based on the CNDs was developed and it provided satisfactory simplicity and sensitivity. Arg can be selectively combined with functional groups on the surface of the CNDs, and effectively quench the fluorescence emission of CNDs. However, in the presence of Cu2+ ions, a more stable Cu–Arg complex formation brings about the fluorescence recovery of CNDs. Meanwhile, the phenomena show a vivid color change visible to the naked eye. Due to the distinct advantages, these fluorescent probes are successfully employed in multicolor cell imaging and can be constructed as an “AND” logic gate at the molecular level. This method displayed more prominent and influential ability in real-time monitoring for applicable purposes, and could be exploited in clinical diagnostics and environmental analysis.
